posts.cooked: I think it would be good as a option if we wanted to camouflage the Signal App on our home screen on ur phone, maybe with a dummy pic and name so if any one looks at ur phone they can‚Äôt tell ur using Signal. Some people get the wrong impression when they see that you are using Signal. What do you think?

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
DarkHorse:

Some people get the wrong impression when they see that you are using Signal.

What impression? If you wrote about Tinder and the like, OK.

And you don‚Äôt have to put it on your homescreen (on most Androids at least, I believe one Chinese brand uses a launcher that resembles Apple).

I am not sure why this is a feature request for signal. You can just change icon/text for yourself if you like, and if your launcher does not support that you should either file a feature request there, or use a launcher that supports it.

On IOS u can‚Äôt change the icons or text, and IOS doesn‚Äôt have secret folders or layouts like Android does where you can hide certain apps. It would be good if we can use a dummy icon and name for the Signal App so when someone looks at ur phones home screen they can‚Äôt tell that you are using Signal

DarkHorse:

I think it would be good as a option if we wanted to camouflage the Signal App on our home screen on ur phone, maybe with a dummy pic and name so if any one looks at ur phone they can‚Äôt tell ur using Signal. Some people get the wrong impression when they see that you are using Signal. What do you think?

Wait, you are afraid, that someone looks on the screen of your phone, discovers Signal, and concludes what kind of person you are? Wow‚Ä¶ never even thought of that, in which country do you live??

posts.name: link ‚ú¶
posts.cooked:
DarkHorse:

On IOS u can‚Äôt change the icons

Actually, it is correct that you can‚Äôt change the icon.

However apps can change their own icon‚Äîthe user would see an alert saying You have changed the icon for "App name" and showing the new icon. Some apps use this functionality and have an icon selector so the user can pick an icon from the set that the app provides.

However I don‚Äôt think changing the app‚Äôs name on the Home screen is possible.

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
On iOS you can put the app in a non-descriptive folder to remove it from view.

But I really wonder where you get a ‚Äúwrong impression‚Äù for using Signal. Perhaps if you work as a contractor for the NSA?

posts.name: link ‚ú¶
posts.cooked:
johanw666:

On iOS you can put the app in a non-descriptive folder to remove it from view.

You can also put some (at least 2 so it‚Äôs not obvious) apps on the first page of the folder, then maybe some apps on other pages, and finally Signal on the last page. Maximum stealth

But I also don‚Äôt understand why exactly the OP wants to hide Signal. I‚Äôd rather prefer to have Signal stand out immediately so people will perhaps want to try it themselves / ask what it is / etc‚Ä¶

posts.name: Laskonova
posts.cooked: Honestly this would be a good feature for people in abusive relationships where their partner has access to their passcode and goes through messaging apps. I‚Äôve been in that situation before. You can get in trouble for deleting messages and saying the wrong thing or trying to keep a part of your phone private. And signal is banned in several counties, Grindr has this feature to keep people slightly safer where being gay is illegal. someone looking though your phone might not think to open a calculator app.

posts.name: mls
posts.cooked: I would say this is a functionality of the launcher app not of Signal itself, setting icon and text the way you described
I know about custom launchers for Android. But as this is a FR for IOS - is the same possible on Apple devices? If not then IMO the request is OK

posts.name: Burt Kobain
posts.cooked: Well, for anyone who lives in or would like to visit countries like Belarus, Turkey, China, North-Korea, Russia, etc. (maybe soon we can add Poland and Hungary to this list?) this could be a lifesaving feature. Myself I don‚Äôt need it, but I can definitely see the use case.

posts.cooked: There have been apps that used to do this in the past where you could choose alternative icons to hide the app and made it look like something else. Apple decided that this wasn‚Äôt allowed anymore and the apps had to remove that feature in order to ship updates.
